speaker: Sam Brownback
vclaim: In countries that allow same-sex marriages, the rates of marriage between the sexes "has fallen to where you now have provinces in Northern Europe where 80 per cent of the first-born children are born out of wedlock."
date: stated on September 5, 2007 in a debate in Durham, N.H.:
title: :: Reduced marriage rates prior to the legalization of same-sex unions
text: In a Republican debate on 5 September 2007, Brownback referred to the argument that conservatives with social values had been presenting them for years on same-sex marriage: such marriage caused lower marriage rates and more births for unmarried couples. However, the trends of low rates of marriage and extramarital births began before the legalization of same-sex marriages. ..................................................................................... Lee Padget, an economist at Massachusetts Amherst University and Director of Research at the Williams Institute of Sexual Orientation and Public Policy of the University of California, wrote a detailed study which examined marriage and birth rates in Scandinavian countries. "The rates of marriage, divorce, and non-marital birth rates in Scandinavia, Europe and the United States have changed over the past 30 years," by Badjit. "But those changes occurred in all countries, regardless of whether or not same-sex partnership laws were adopted, and these trends were taking place before laws giving same-sex couples rights were enacted." In Denmark, Norway and Sweden, same-sex partnerships were legalized in 1989, 1993 and 1994, respectively. In general, gay partners in these countries enjoy legal and financial protection for marriage, but are not allowed to marry in church or adopt children. Governor Stanley Kurtz is a prominent advocate of the argument that same-sex marriage is harmful to marriage between the sexes. Kurtz responded to the Padjit study by claiming that marriage rates in Scandinavia and other European countries were still declining, and that the legalization of same-sex partnerships was "retrogression of forces and intensification of parental coexistence."
